none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. H. Whitlock, December 28, 1884
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. H. Whitlock, December 28, 1884
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 18 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
JAS. M. CARLISLE, PRES'T,
Whitesboro.
MISS NANNIE C. BREEDING,
V. Pres't, Houston.
ROB'T F. SMITH, SEC'Y,
College Station.
MISS JOSIE L. WOOD,
Assistant Secretary, Brenham.

TEACHERS'
New Orleans Excursion
ASSOCIATION.

Executive Committee.
J. M. CARLISLE,
Whitesboro.
R. F. SMITH,
College Station.
A. H. WILKINS,
Houston.

New-Orleans 12/28 1884.

Dear Mc Innis,
I have been so
busy that the time has fairly
fulfilled the old adage and actually
"fuges". We have been going round
the city for a few days. The Expo
sition is way behind and I think
it will be at least a month
before things are ready in all
departments. Mother arrived all
right and feels very well apparent
ly, and is enjoying herself to
the "full bent". Our plans at
present are to leave here Friday Jan
2nd, and expect to get to College Sta
tion the next day at 2. P.M. Will
write you again before that time.
Remember me to all. Mallory not
back from Jackson yet. R. H. Whitlock

**Here's how I approached this transcription task:** First, I assessed the parameters: I'm a transcriptionist, my task is to transcribe this image of a letter, following the given guidelines. The key directives are to maintain natural reading order, ensure high accuracy (including original spelling and punctuation), interpret any handwriting, adhere to the specified HTML tags, and present lists in a Markdown table. Commentary is not requested. Then, I carefully examined the image, starting with the letterhead. I parsed the left side (officers and locations), the center ("TEACHERS'â€¦"), and the right side (Executive Committee and locations). I took note of the handwritten date/location ("New Orleans 12/28 1884"), salutation ("Dear McInnis"), and the body of the letter itself, focusing on spelling (e.g., "fuges"), punctuation, and line breaks. I paid close attention to the emphasized words and phrases within the body of the letter. Finally, I examined the signature ("R. H. Whitlock"). Next, I started drafting the transcription. I tackled the letterhead's structure, recognizing the need to replicate its layout. I used HTML tags to represent the side columns and centered title. Then, I transcribed the date, salutation, and body, accounting for any line breaks in the body. I meticulously transcribed the text, including the writer's idiosyncratic "fuges". After creating the draft, I refined the transcription's formatting. I ensured I adhered to the HTML tags, especially regarding the forbidden `` tag. I opted for `` to represent the emphasis/underlining for the word "least". I also considered the need to retain the visual layout with `

` and `
`. Then, I performed a final visual check on layout and spacing. I reevaluated the letterhead layout, aiming for a logical presentation based on the guideline "Natural top-to-bottom, left-to-right", and the reading hierarchy. I then made sure to arrange the left block, center title, and right block in order. I then did a detailed evaluation of each detail of the handwriting: * "New-Orleans" included a dash. * "12/28" - the 28 is slightly subscript but it's a fraction style. * "Mc Innis" - there is a space. * "fuges" - quotes are distinct. * "least" - underlined. I'll use `` as `` is forbidden. * "full bent" - quotes distinct. * "2. P.M." - dots used. * "R. H. Whitlock" - Signature is at the bottom right. Finally, I assembled the final output, paying extra attention to the details of the handwriting and the required formatting. I double-checked the date and signature one last time before submitting the transcription, making sure it met all of the requirements.
